018package org.opengis.filter;
019
020import java.time.Instant;
021import java.util.List;
022import java.util.Objects;
023import java.util.Collection;
024import javax.measure.Quantity;
025import javax.measure.quantity.Length;
026import org.opengis.util.Factory;
027import org.opengis.geometry.Geometry;
028import org.opengis.geometry.Envelope;
029import org.opengis.filter.capability.FilterCapabilities;
030
031
032/**
033 * Factory of instances of the various {@link Filter} and {@link Expression} subclasses.
034 *
035 * @todo This interface is a first draft. Its API may change at any time.
036 * In particular different strategies may be tried regarding the parameterized types.
037 *
038 * @author  Chris Dillard (SYS Technologies)
039 * @author  Jody Garnett (Refractions Research Inc.)
040 * @author  Johann Sorel (Geomatys)
041 * @author  Martin Desruisseaux (Geomatys)
042 * @version 3.1
043 *
044 * @param  <R>  the type of resources (e.g. {@link org.opengis.feature.Feature}) to use as inputs.
045 * @param  <G>  base class of geometry objects. The implementation-neutral type is GeoAPI {@link Geometry}.
046 * @param  <T>  base class of temporal objects.
047 *
048 * @since 3.1
049 */
050public interface FilterFactory<R,G,T> extends Factory {
051    /**
052     * Describes the abilities of this factory. The description includes restrictions
053     * on the available spatial operations, scalar operations, lists of supported functions,
054     * and description of which geometry literals are understood.
055     *
056     * @return description of the abilities of this factory.
057     */
058    FilterCapabilities getCapabilities();
059
060    /**
061     * Creates a predicate to identify an identifiable resource within a filter expression.
062     * The predicate uses no versioning and no time range.
063     *
064     * @param  rid  identifier of the resource that shall be selected by the predicate.
065     * @return the predicate.
066     */
067    default ResourceId<R> resourceId(final String rid) {
068        return resourceId(rid, null, null, null);
069    }
070
071    /**
072     * Creates a predicate to identify an identifiable resource within a filter expression.
073     * If {@code startTime} and {@code endTime} are non-null, the filter will select all versions
074     * of a resource between the specified dates.
075     *
076     * @param  rid        identifier of the resource that shall be selected by the predicate.
077     * @param  version    version of the resource to select, or {@code null} for any version.
078     * @param  startTime  start time of the resource to select, or {@code null} if none.
079     * @param  endTime    end time of the resource to select, or {@code null} if none.
080     * @return the predicate.
081     */
082    ResourceId<R> resourceId(String rid, Version version, Instant startTime, Instant endTime);
083
084    /**
085     * Creates an expression whose value is computed by retrieving the value indicated by a path in a resource.
086     * If all characters in the path are {@linkplain Character#isUnicodeIdentifierPart(int) Unicode identifier parts},
087     * then the XPath expression is simply a property name.
088     *
089     * @param  xpath  the path to the property whose value will be returned by the {@code apply(R)} method.
090     * @return an expression evaluating the referenced property value.
091     */
092    default ValueReference<R,?> property(String xpath) {
093        return property(xpath, Object.class);
094    }
095
096    /**
097     * Creates an expression retrieving the value as an instance of the specified class.
098     * The {@code xpath} argument follows the rule described in {@link #property(String)}.
099     *
100     * <p>The desired type of property values can be specified. For example if the property values should be numbers,
101     * then {@code type} can be <code>{@linkplain Number}.class</code>. If property values can be of any type with no
102     * conversion desired, then {@code type} should be {@code Object.class}.</p>
103     *
104     * @param  <V>    the type of the values to be fetched (compile-time value of {@code type}).
105     * @param  xpath  the path to the property whose value will be returned by the {@code apply(R)} method.
106     * @param  type   the type of the values to be fetched (run-time value of {@code <V>}).
107     * @return an expression evaluating the referenced property value.
108     */
109    <V> ValueReference<R,V> property(String xpath, Class<V> type);
110
111    /**
112     * Creates a constant, literal value that can be used in expressions.
113     *
114     * <h4>Recommended restriction</h4>
115     * The given value may be persisted with XML based technologies.
116     * As an example a {@link Geometry} may be written out using GML.
117     * Consequently, the value should be data objects such as strings, numbers, dates, or geometries.
118     * It should not be state of operations.
119     *
120     * @param  <V>    the type of the value of the literal.
121     * @param  value  the literal value. May be {@code null}.
122     * @return a literal for the given value.
123     */
124    <V> Literal<R,V> literal(V value);
125
126    /**
127     * Filter operator that compares that its two sub-expressions are equal to each other.
128     * The comparison is case-sensitive and evaluates to {@code true} if {@linkplain MatchAction#ANY Any}
129     * of the value in the collection can satisfy the predicate.
130     *
131     * @param  expression1  the first of the two expressions to be used by this comparator.
132     * @param  expression2  the second of the two expressions to be used by this comparator.
133     * @return a filter evaluating {@code expression1} = {@code expression2}.
134     *
135     * @see ComparisonOperatorName#PROPERTY_IS_EQUAL_TO
136     */
137    default BinaryComparisonOperator<R> equal(Expression<R,?> expression1,
138                                              Expression<R,?> expression2)
139    {
140        return equal(Objects.requireNonNull(expression1),
141                     Objects.requireNonNull(expression2),
142                     true, MatchAction.ANY);
143    }
144
145    /**
146     * Filter operator that compares that its two sub-expressions are equal to each other.
147     *
148     * @param  expression1     the first of the two expressions to be used by this comparator.
149     * @param  expression2     the second of the two expressions to be used by this comparator.
150     * @param  isMatchingCase  specifies whether comparisons are case sensitive.
151     * @param  matchAction     specifies how the comparisons shall be evaluated for a collection of values.
152     * @return a filter evaluating {@code expression1} = {@code expression2}.
153     *
154     * @see ComparisonOperatorName#PROPERTY_IS_EQUAL_TO
155     */
156    BinaryComparisonOperator<R> equal(Expression<R,?> expression1,
157                                      Expression<R,?> expression2,
158                                      boolean isMatchingCase, MatchAction matchAction);
159
160    /**
161     * Filter operator that compares that its two sub-expressions are not equal to each other.
162     * The comparison is case-sensitive and evaluates to {@code true} if {@linkplain MatchAction#ANY Any}
163     * of the value in the collection can satisfy the predicate.
164     *
165     * @param  expression1  the first of the two expressions to be used by this comparator.
166     * @param  expression2  the second of the two expressions to be used by this comparator.
167     * @return a filter evaluating {@code expression1} ≠ {@code expression2}.
168     *
169     * @see ComparisonOperatorName#PROPERTY_IS_NOT_EQUAL_TO
170     */
171    default BinaryComparisonOperator<R> notEqual(Expression<R,?> expression1,
172                                                 Expression<R,?> expression2)
173    {
174        return notEqual(Objects.requireNonNull(expression1),
175                        Objects.requireNonNull(expression2),
176                        true, MatchAction.ANY);
177    }
178
179    /**
180     * Filter operator that compares that its two sub-expressions are not equal to each other.
181     *
182     * @param  expression1     the first of the two expressions to be used by this comparator.
183     * @param  expression2     the second of the two expressions to be used by this comparator.
184     * @param  isMatchingCase  specifies whether comparisons are case sensitive.
185     * @param  matchAction     specifies how the comparisons shall be evaluated for a collection of values.
186     * @return a filter evaluating {@code expression1} ≠ {@code expression2}.
187     *
188     * @see ComparisonOperatorName#PROPERTY_IS_NOT_EQUAL_TO
189     */
190    BinaryComparisonOperator<R> notEqual(Expression<R,?> expression1,
191                                         Expression<R,?> expression2,
192                                         boolean isMatchingCase, MatchAction matchAction);
193
194    /**
195     * Filter operator that checks that its first sub-expression is less than its second sub-expression.
196     * The comparison is case-sensitive and evaluates to {@code true} if {@linkplain MatchAction#ANY Any}
197     * of the value in the collection can satisfy the predicate.
198     *
199     * @param  expression1  the first of the two expressions to be used by this comparator.
200     * @param  expression2  the second of the two expressions to be used by this comparator.
201     * @return a filter evaluating {@code expression1} &lt; {@code expression2}.
202     *
203     * @see ComparisonOperatorName#PROPERTY_IS_LESS_THAN
204     * @todo Revisit if we can be more specific on the second parameterized type in expressions.
205     */
206    default BinaryComparisonOperator<R> less(Expression<R,?> expression1,
207                                             Expression<R,?> expression2)
208    {
209        return less(Objects.requireNonNull(expression1),
210                    Objects.requireNonNull(expression2),
211                    true, MatchAction.ANY);
212    }
213
214    /**
215     * Filter operator that checks that its first sub-expression is less than its second sub-expression.
216     *
217     * @param  expression1     the first of the two expressions to be used by this comparator.
218     * @param  expression2     the second of the two expressions to be used by this comparator.
219     * @param  isMatchingCase  specifies whether comparisons are case sensitive.
220     * @param  matchAction     specifies how the comparisons shall be evaluated for a collection of values.
221     * @return a filter evaluating {@code expression1} &lt; {@code expression2}.
222     *
223     * @see ComparisonOperatorName#PROPERTY_IS_LESS_THAN
224     * @todo Revisit if we can be more specific on the second parameterized type in expressions.
225     */
226    BinaryComparisonOperator<R> less(Expression<R,?> expression1,
227                                     Expression<R,?> expression2,
228                                     boolean isMatchingCase, MatchAction matchAction);
229
230    /**
231     * Filter operator that checks that its first sub-expression is greater than its second sub-expression.
232     * The comparison is case-sensitive and evaluates to {@code true} if {@linkplain MatchAction#ANY Any}
233     * of the value in the collection can satisfy the predicate.
234     *
235     * @param  expression1  the first of the two expressions to be used by this comparator.
236     * @param  expression2  the second of the two expressions to be used by this comparator.
237     * @return a filter evaluating {@code expression1} &gt; {@code expression2}.
238     *
239     * @see ComparisonOperatorName#PROPERTY_IS_GREATER_THAN
240     * @todo Revisit if we can be more specific on the second parameterized type in expressions.
241     */
242    default BinaryComparisonOperator<R> greater(Expression<R,?> expression1,
243                                                Expression<R,?> expression2)
244    {
245        return greater(Objects.requireNonNull(expression1),
246                       Objects.requireNonNull(expression2),
247                       true, MatchAction.ANY);
248    }
249
250    /**
251     * Filter operator that checks that its first sub-expression is greater than its second sub-expression.
252     *
253     * @param  expression1     the first of the two expressions to be used by this comparator.
254     * @param  expression2     the second of the two expressions to be used by this comparator.
255     * @param  isMatchingCase  specifies whether comparisons are case sensitive.
256     * @param  matchAction     specifies how the comparisons shall be evaluated for a collection of values.
257     * @return a filter evaluating {@code expression1} &gt; {@code expression2}.
258     *
259     * @see ComparisonOperatorName#PROPERTY_IS_GREATER_THAN
260     * @todo Revisit if we can be more specific on the second parameterized type in expressions.
261     */
262    BinaryComparisonOperator<R> greater(Expression<R,?> expression1,
263                                        Expression<R,?> expression2,
264                                        boolean isMatchingCase, MatchAction matchAction);
265
266    /**
267     * Filter operator that checks that its first sub-expression is less than or equal to its second sub-expression.
268     * The comparison is case-sensitive and evaluates to {@code true} if {@linkplain MatchAction#ANY Any}
269     * of the value in the collection can satisfy the predicate.
270     *
271     * @param  expression1  the first of the two expressions to be used by this comparator.
272     * @param  expression2  the second of the two expressions to be used by this comparator.
273     * @return a filter evaluating {@code expression1} ≤ {@code expression2}.
274     *
275     * @see ComparisonOperatorName#PROPERTY_IS_LESS_THAN_OR_EQUAL_TO
276     * @todo Revisit if we can be more specific on the second parameterized type in expressions.
277     */
278    default BinaryComparisonOperator<R> lessOrEqual(Expression<R,?> expression1,
279                                                    Expression<R,?> expression2)
280    {
281        return lessOrEqual(Objects.requireNonNull(expression1),
282                           Objects.requireNonNull(expression2),
283                           true, MatchAction.ANY);
284    }
285
286    /**
287     * Filter operator that checks that its first sub-expression is less than or equal to its second sub-expression.
288     *
289     * @param  expression1     the first of the two expressions to be used by this comparator.
290     * @param  expression2     the second of the two expressions to be used by this comparator.
291     * @param  isMatchingCase  specifies whether comparisons are case sensitive.
292     * @param  matchAction     specifies how the comparisons shall be evaluated for a collection of values.
293     * @return a filter evaluating {@code expression1} ≤ {@code expression2}.
294     *
295     * @see ComparisonOperatorName#PROPERTY_IS_LESS_THAN_OR_EQUAL_TO
296     * @todo Revisit if we can be more specific on the second parameterized type in expressions.
297     */
298    BinaryComparisonOperator<R> lessOrEqual(Expression<R,?> expression1,
299                                            Expression<R,?> expression2,
300                                            boolean isMatchingCase, MatchAction matchAction);
301
302    /**
303     * Filter operator that checks that its first sub-expression is greater than its second sub-expression.
304     * The comparison is case-sensitive and evaluates to {@code true} if {@linkplain MatchAction#ANY Any}
305     * of the value in the collection can satisfy the predicate.
306     *
307     * @param  expression1  the first of the two expressions to be used by this comparator.
308     * @param  expression2  the second of the two expressions to be used by this comparator.
309     * @return a filter evaluating {@code expression1} ≥ {@code expression2}.
310     *
311     * @see ComparisonOperatorName#PROPERTY_IS_GREATER_THAN_OR_EQUAL_TO
312     * @todo Revisit if we can be more specific on the second parameterized type in expressions.
313     */
314    default BinaryComparisonOperator<R> greaterOrEqual(Expression<R,?> expression1,
315                                                       Expression<R,?> expression2)
316    {
317        return greaterOrEqual(Objects.requireNonNull(expression1),
318                              Objects.requireNonNull(expression2),
319                              true, MatchAction.ANY);
320    }
321
322    /**
323     * Filter operator that checks that its first sub-expression is greater than its second sub-expression.
324     *
325     * @param  expression1     the first of the two expressions to be used by this comparator.
326     * @param  expression2     the second of the two expressions to be used by this comparator.
327     * @param  isMatchingCase  specifies whether comparisons are case sensitive.
328     * @param  matchAction     specifies how the comparisons shall be evaluated for a collection of values.
329     * @return a filter evaluating {@code expression1} ≥ {@code expression2}.
330     *
331     * @see ComparisonOperatorName#PROPERTY_IS_GREATER_THAN_OR_EQUAL_TO
332     * @todo Revisit if we can be more specific on the second parameterized type in expressions.
333     */
334    BinaryComparisonOperator<R> greaterOrEqual(Expression<R,?> expression1,
335                                               Expression<R,?> expression2,
336                                               boolean isMatchingCase, MatchAction matchAction);
337
338    /**
339     * Filter operation for a range check.
340     * The lower and upper boundary values are inclusive.
341     *
342     * @param  expression     the expression to be compared by this comparator.
343     * @param  lowerBoundary  the lower bound (inclusive) as an expression.
344     * @param  upperBoundary  the upper bound (inclusive) as an expression.
345     * @return a filter evaluating ({@code expression} ≥ {@code lowerBoundary})
346     *                       &amp; ({@code expression} ≤ {@code upperBoundary}).
347     */
348    BetweenComparisonOperator<R> between(Expression<R,?> expression,
349                                         Expression<R,?> lowerBoundary,
350                                         Expression<R,?> upperBoundary);
351
352    /**
353     * Character string comparison operator with pattern matching and default wildcards.
354     * The wildcard character is {@code '%'}, the single character is {@code '_'} and
355     * the escape character is {@code '\\'}. The comparison is case-sensitive.
356     *
357     * @param  expression  source of values to compare against the pattern.
358     * @param  pattern     pattern to match against expression values.
359     * @return a character string comparison operator with pattern matching.
360     */
361    default LikeOperator<R> like(Expression<R,?> expression, String pattern) {
362        return like(Objects.requireNonNull(expression), Objects.requireNonNull(pattern), '%', '_', '\\', true);
363    }
364
365    /**
366     * Character string comparison operator with pattern matching and specified wildcards.
367     *
368     * @param  expression      source of values to compare against the pattern.
369     * @param  pattern         pattern to match against expression values.
370     * @param  wildcard        pattern character for matching any sequence of characters.
371     * @param  singleChar      pattern character for matching exactly one character.
372     * @param  escape          pattern character for indicating that the next character should be matched literally.
373     * @param  isMatchingCase  specifies how a filter expression processor should perform string comparisons.
374     * @return a character string comparison operator with pattern matching.
375     */
376    LikeOperator<R> like(Expression<R,?> expression, String pattern,
377            char wildcard, char singleChar, char escape, boolean isMatchingCase);
378
379    /**
380     * An operator that tests if an expression's value is {@code null}.
381     * This corresponds to checking whether the property exists in the real-world.
382     *
383     * @param  expression  source of values to compare against {@code null}.
384     * @return a filter that checks if an expression's value is {@code null}.
385     */
386    NullOperator<R> isNull(Expression<R,?> expression);
387
388    /**
389     * An operator that tests if an expression's value is nil.
390     * The difference with {@link NullOperator} is that a value should exist
391     * but cannot be provided for the reason given by {@code nilReason}.
392     * Possible reasons are:
393     *
394     * <ul>
395     *   <li><b>inapplicable</b> — there is no value.</li>
396     *   <li><b>template</b>     — the value will be available later.</li>
397     *   <li><b>missing</b>      — the correct value is not readily available to the sender of this data.
398     *                             Furthermore, a correct value may not exist.</li>
399     *   <li><b>unknown</b>      — the correct value is not known to, and not computable by, the sender of this data.
400     *                             However, a correct value probably exists..</li>
401     *   <li><b>withheld</b>     — the value is not divulged.</li>
402     *   <li>Other strings at implementation choice.</li>
403     * </ul>
404     *
405     * @param  expression  source of values to compare against nil values.
406     * @param  nilReason   the reason why the value is nil, or {@code null} for accepting any reason.
407     * @return a filter that checks if an expression's value is nil for the specified reason.
408     */
409    NilOperator<R> isNil(Expression<R,?> expression, String nilReason);
410
411    /**
412     * Creates a {@code AND} filter between two filters.
413     *
414     * @param  operand1  the first operand of the AND operation.
415     * @param  operand2  the second operand of the AND operation.
416     * @return a filter evaluating {@code operand1 AND operand2}.
417     *
418     * @see LogicalOperatorName#AND
419     */
420    default LogicalOperator<R> and(Filter<R> operand1, Filter<R> operand2) {
421        return and(List.<Filter<R>>of(Objects.requireNonNull(operand1),
422                                      Objects.requireNonNull(operand2)));
423    }
424
425    /**
426     * Creates a {@code AND} filter between two or more filters.
427     *
428     * @param  operands  a collection of at least 2 operands.
429     * @return a filter evaluating {@code operand1 AND operand2 AND operand3}…
430     * @throws IllegalArgumentException if the given collection contains less than 2 elements.
431     *
432     * @see LogicalOperatorName#AND
433     */
434    LogicalOperator<R> and(Collection<? extends Filter<R>> operands);
435
436    /**
437     * Creates a {@code OR} filter between two filters.
438     *
439     * @param  operand1  the first operand of the OR operation.
440     * @param  operand2  the second operand of the OR operation.
441     * @return a filter evaluating {@code operand1 OR operand2}.
442     *
443     * @see LogicalOperatorName#OR
444     */
445    default LogicalOperator<R> or(Filter<R> operand1, Filter<R> operand2) {
446        return or(List.<Filter<R>>of(Objects.requireNonNull(operand1),
447                                     Objects.requireNonNull(operand2)));
448    }
449
450    /**
451     * Creates a {@code OR} filter between two or more filters.
452     *
453     * @param  operands  a collection of at least 2 operands.
454     * @return a filter evaluating {@code operand1 OR operand2 OR operand3}…
455     * @throws IllegalArgumentException if the given collection contains less than 2 elements.
456     *
457     * @see LogicalOperatorName#OR
458     */
459    LogicalOperator<R> or(Collection<? extends Filter<R>> operands);
460
461    /**
462     * Creates a {@code NOT} filter for the given filter.
463     *
464     * @param  operand  the operand of the NOT operation.
465     * @return a filter evaluating {@code NOT operand}.
466     *
467     * @see LogicalOperatorName#NOT
468     */
469    LogicalOperator<R> not(Filter<R> operand);
470
471////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
472//
473//  SPATIAL FILTERS
474//
475////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
476
477    /**
478     * Creates an operator that checks if the bounding box of the feature's geometry interacts
479     * with the bounding box provided in the filter properties.
480     *
481     * @param  geometry  expression fetching the geometry to check for interaction with bounds.
482     * @param  bounds    the bounds to check geometry against.
483     * @return a filter checking for any interactions between the bounding boxes.
484     *
485     * @see SpatialOperatorName#BBOX
486     */
487    BinarySpatialOperator<R> bbox(Expression<R, ? extends G> geometry, Envelope bounds);
488
489    /**
490     * Creates an operator that checks if the geometry of the two operands are equal.
491     *
492     * @param  geometry1  expression fetching the first geometry of the binary operator.
493     * @param  geometry2  expression fetching the second geometry of the binary operator.
494     * @return a filter for the "Equals" operator between the two geometries.
495     *
496     * @see SpatialOperatorName#EQUALS
497     *
498     * @todo Rename {@code equal}.
499     */
500    BinarySpatialOperator<R> equals(Expression<R, ? extends G> geometry1,
501                                    Expression<R, ? extends G> geometry2);
502
503    /**
504     * Creates an operator that checks if the first operand is disjoint from the second.
505     *
506     * @param  geometry1  expression fetching the first geometry of the binary operator.
507     * @param  geometry2  expression fetching the second geometry of the binary operator.
508     * @return a filter for the "Disjoint" operator between the two geometries.
509     *
510     * @see SpatialOperatorName#DISJOINT
511     */
512    BinarySpatialOperator<R> disjoint(Expression<R, ? extends G> geometry1,
513                                      Expression<R, ? extends G> geometry2);
514
515    /**
516     * Creates an operator that checks if the two geometric operands intersect.
517     *
518     * @param  geometry1  expression fetching the first geometry of the binary operator.
519     * @param  geometry2  expression fetching the second geometry of the binary operator.
520     * @return a filter for the "Intersects" operator between the two geometries.
521     *
522     * @see SpatialOperatorName#INTERSECTS
523     */
524    BinarySpatialOperator<R> intersects(Expression<R, ? extends G> geometry1,
525                                        Expression<R, ? extends G> geometry2);
526
527    /**
528     * Creates an operator that checks if the two geometric operands touch each other, but do not overlap.
529     *
530     * @param  geometry1  expression fetching the first geometry of the binary operator.
531     * @param  geometry2  expression fetching the second geometry of the binary operator.
532     * @return a filter for the "Touches" operator between the two geometries.
533     *
534     * @see SpatialOperatorName#TOUCHES
535     */
536    BinarySpatialOperator<R> touches(Expression<R, ? extends G> geometry1,
537                                     Expression<R, ? extends G> geometry2);
538
539    /**
540     * Creates an operator that checks if the first geometric operand crosses the second.
541     *
542     * @param  geometry1  expression fetching the first geometry of the binary operator.
543     * @param  geometry2  expression fetching the second geometry of the binary operator.
544     * @return a filter for the "Crosses" operator between the two geometries.
545     *
546     * @see SpatialOperatorName#CROSSES
547     */
548    BinarySpatialOperator<R> crosses(Expression<R, ? extends G> geometry1,
549                                     Expression<R, ? extends G> geometry2);
550
551    /**
552     * Creates an operator that checks if the first geometric operand is completely
553     * contained by the constant geometric operand.
554     *
555     * @param  geometry1  expression fetching the first geometry of the binary operator.
556     * @param  geometry2  expression fetching the second geometry of the binary operator.
557     * @return a filter for the "Within" operator between the two geometries.
558     *
559     * @see SpatialOperatorName#WITHIN
560     */
561    BinarySpatialOperator<R> within(Expression<R, ? extends G> geometry1,
562                                    Expression<R, ? extends G> geometry2);
563
564    /**
565     * Creates an operator that checks if the first geometric operand contains the second.
566     *
567     * @param  geometry1  expression fetching the first geometry of the binary operator.
568     * @param  geometry2  expression fetching the second geometry of the binary operator.
569     * @return a filter for the "Contains" operator between the two geometries.
570     *
571     * @see SpatialOperatorName#CONTAINS
572     */
573    BinarySpatialOperator<R> contains(Expression<R, ? extends G> geometry1,
574                                      Expression<R, ? extends G> geometry2);
575
576    /**
577     * Creates an operator that checks if the interior of the first geometric operand
578     * somewhere overlaps the interior of the second geometric operand.
579     *
580     * @param  geometry1  expression fetching the first geometry of the binary operator.
581     * @param  geometry2  expression fetching the second geometry of the binary operator.
582     * @return a filter for the "Overlaps" operator between the two geometries.
583     *
584     * @see SpatialOperatorName#OVERLAPS
585     */
586    BinarySpatialOperator<R>  overlaps(Expression<R, ? extends G> geometry1,
587                                       Expression<R, ? extends G> geometry2);
588
589    /**
590     * Creates an operator that checks if all of a feature's geometry is more distant
591     * than the given distance from the given geometry.
592     *
593     * @param  geometry1  expression fetching the first geometry of the binary operator.
594     * @param  geometry2  expression fetching the second geometry of the binary operator.
595     * @param  distance   minimal distance for evaluating the expression as {@code true}.
596     * @return operator that evaluates to {@code true} when all of a feature's geometry
597     *         is more distant than the given distance from the second geometry.
598     *
599     * @see DistanceOperatorName#BEYOND
600     */
601    DistanceOperator<R> beyond(Expression<R, ? extends G> geometry1,
602                               Expression<R, ? extends G> geometry2,
603                               Quantity<Length> distance);
604
605    /**
606     * Creates an operator that checks if any part of the first geometry lies within
607     * the given distance of the second geometry.
608     *
609     * @param  geometry1  expression fetching the first geometry of the binary operator.
610     * @param  geometry2  expression fetching the second geometry of the binary operator.
611     * @param  distance   maximal distance for evaluating the expression as {@code true}.
612     * @return operator that evaluates to {@code true} when any part of the feature's geometry
613     *         lies within the given distance of the second geometry.
614     *
615     * @see DistanceOperatorName#WITHIN
616     */
617    DistanceOperator<R> within(Expression<R, ? extends G> geometry1,
618                               Expression<R, ? extends G> geometry2,
619                               Quantity<Length> distance);
620
621////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
622//
623//  TEMPORAL FILTERS
624//
625////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
626
627    /**
628     * Creates an operator that checks if first temporal operand is after the second.
629     *
630     * @param  time1  expression fetching the first temporal value.
631     * @param  time2  expression fetching the second temporal value.
632     * @return a filter for the "After" operator between the two temporal values.
633     *
634     * @see TemporalOperatorName#AFTER
635     */
636    TemporalOperator<R> after(Expression<R, ? extends T> time1,
637                              Expression<R, ? extends T> time2);
638
639    /**
640     * Creates an operator that checks if first temporal operand is before the second.
641     *
642     * @param  time1  expression fetching the first temporal value.
643     * @param  time2  expression fetching the second temporal value.
644     * @return a filter for the "Before" operator between the two temporal values.
645     *
646     * @see TemporalOperatorName#BEFORE
647     */
648    TemporalOperator<R> before(Expression<R, ? extends T> time1,
649                               Expression<R, ? extends T> time2);
650
651    /**
652     * Creates an operator that checks if first temporal operand begins at the second.
653     *
654     * @param  time1  expression fetching the first temporal value.
655     * @param  time2  expression fetching the second temporal value.
656     * @return a filter for the "Begins" operator between the two temporal values.
657     *
658     * @see TemporalOperatorName#BEGINS
659     */
660    TemporalOperator<R> begins(Expression<R, ? extends T> time1,
661                               Expression<R, ? extends T> time2);
662
663    /**
664     * Creates an operator that checks if first temporal operand begun by the second.
665     *
666     * @param  time1  expression fetching the first temporal value.
667     * @param  time2  expression fetching the second temporal value.
668     * @return a filter for the "BegunBy" operator between the two temporal values.
669     *
670     * @see TemporalOperatorName#BEGUN_BY
671     */
672    TemporalOperator<R> begunBy(Expression<R, ? extends T> time1,
673                                Expression<R, ? extends T> time2);
674
675    /**
676     * Creates an operator that checks if first temporal operand is contained by the second.
677     *
678     * @param  time1  expression fetching the first temporal value.
679     * @param  time2  expression fetching the second temporal value.
680     * @return a filter for the "TContains" operator between the two temporal values.
681     *
682     * @see TemporalOperatorName#CONTAINS
683     */
684    TemporalOperator<R> tcontains(Expression<R, ? extends T> time1,
685                                  Expression<R, ? extends T> time2);
686
687    /**
688     * Creates an operator that checks if first temporal operand is during the second.
689     *
690     * @param  time1  expression fetching the first temporal value.
691     * @param  time2  expression fetching the second temporal value.
692     * @return a filter for the "During" operator between the two temporal values.
693     *
694     * @see TemporalOperatorName#DURING
695     */
696    TemporalOperator<R> during(Expression<R, ? extends T> time1,
697                               Expression<R, ? extends T> time2);
698
699    /**
700     * Creates an operator that checks if first temporal operand is equal to the second.
701     *
702     * @param  time1  expression fetching the first temporal value.
703     * @param  time2  expression fetching the second temporal value.
704     * @return a filter for the "TEquals" operator between the two temporal values.
705     *
706     * @see TemporalOperatorName#EQUALS
707     */
708    TemporalOperator<R> tequals(Expression<R, ? extends T> time1,
709                                Expression<R, ? extends T> time2);
710
711    /**
712     * Creates an operator that checks if first temporal operand overlaps the second.
713     *
714     * @param  time1  expression fetching the first temporal value.
715     * @param  time2  expression fetching the second temporal value.
716     * @return a filter for the "TOverlaps" operator between the two temporal values.
717     *
718     * @see TemporalOperatorName#OVERLAPS
719     */
720    TemporalOperator<R> toverlaps(Expression<R, ? extends T> time1,
721                                  Expression<R, ? extends T> time2);
722
723    /**
724     * Creates an operator that checks if first temporal operand meets the second.
725     *
726     * @param  time1  expression fetching the first temporal value.
727     * @param  time2  expression fetching the second temporal value.
728     * @return a filter for the "Meets" operator between the two temporal values.
729     *
730     * @see TemporalOperatorName#MEETS
731     */
732    TemporalOperator<R> meets(Expression<R, ? extends T> time1,
733                              Expression<R, ? extends T> time2);
734
735    /**
736     * Creates an operator that checks if first temporal operand ends at the second.
737     *
738     * @param  time1  expression fetching the first temporal value.
739     * @param  time2  expression fetching the second temporal value.
740     * @return a filter for the "Ends" operator between the two temporal values.
741     *
742     * @see TemporalOperatorName#ENDS
743     */
744    TemporalOperator<R> ends(Expression<R, ? extends T> time1,
745                             Expression<R, ? extends T> time2);
746
747    /**
748     * Creates an operator that checks if first temporal operand is overlapped by the second.
749     *
750     * @param  time1  expression fetching the first temporal value.
751     * @param  time2  expression fetching the second temporal value.
752     * @return a filter for the "OverlappedBy" operator between the two temporal values.
753     *
754     * @see TemporalOperatorName#OVERLAPPED_BY
755     */
756    TemporalOperator<R> overlappedBy(Expression<R, ? extends T> time1,
757                                     Expression<R, ? extends T> time2);
758
759    /**
760     * Creates an operator that checks if first temporal operand is met by the second.
761     *
762     * @param  time1  expression fetching the first temporal value.
763     * @param  time2  expression fetching the second temporal value.
764     * @return a filter for the "MetBy" operator between the two temporal values.
765     *
766     * @see TemporalOperatorName#MET_BY
767     */
768    TemporalOperator<R> metBy(Expression<R, ? extends T> time1,
769                              Expression<R, ? extends T> time2);
770
771    /**
772     * Creates an operator that checks if first temporal operand is ended by the second.
773     *
774     * @param  time1  expression fetching the first temporal value.
775     * @param  time2  expression fetching the second temporal value.
776     * @return a filter for the "EndedBy" operator between the two temporal values.
777     *
778     * @see TemporalOperatorName#ENDED_BY
779     */
780    TemporalOperator<R> endedBy(Expression<R, ? extends T> time1,
781                                Expression<R, ? extends T> time2);
782
783    /**
784     * Creates a shortcut operator semantically equivalent to NOT (Before OR Meets OR MetBy OR After).
785     * This is applicable to periods only.
786     *
787     * @param  time1  expression fetching the first temporal value.
788     * @param  time2  expression fetching the second temporal value.
789     * @return a filter for the "AnyInteracts" operator between the two temporal values.
790     *
791     * @see TemporalOperatorName#ANY_INTERACTS
792     */
793    TemporalOperator<R> anyInteracts(Expression<R, ? extends T> time1,
794                                     Expression<R, ? extends T> time2);
795
796////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
797//
798//  MISCELLANEOUS
799//
800////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
801
802    /**
803     * Creates a function computing the numeric addition of the first and second operand.
804     *
805     * @param  operand1  expression fetching the first number.
806     * @param  operand2  expression fetching the second number.
807     * @return an expression for the "Add" function between the two numerical values.
808     */
809    Expression<R,Number> add(Expression<R, ? extends Number> operand1,
810                             Expression<R, ? extends Number> operand2);
811
812    /**
813     * Creates a function computing the numeric difference between the first and second operand.
814     *
815     * @param  operand1  expression fetching the first number.
816     * @param  operand2  expression fetching the second number.
817     * @return an expression for the "Subtract" function between the two numerical values.
818     */
819    Expression<R,Number> subtract(Expression<R, ? extends Number> operand1,
820                                  Expression<R, ? extends Number> operand2);
821
822    /**
823     * Creates a function computing the numeric product of their first and second operand.
824     *
825     * @param  operand1  expression fetching the first number.
826     * @param  operand2  expression fetching the second number.
827     * @return an expression for the "Multiply" function between the two numerical values.
828     */
829    Expression<R,Number> multiply(Expression<R, ? extends Number> operand1,
830                                  Expression<R, ? extends Number> operand2);
831
832    /**
833     * Creates a function computing the numeric quotient resulting from dividing the first operand by the second.
834     *
835     * @param  operand1  expression fetching the first number.
836     * @param  operand2  expression fetching the second number.
837     * @return an expression for the "Divide" function between the two numerical values.
838     */
839    Expression<R,Number> divide(Expression<R, ? extends Number> operand1,
840                                Expression<R, ? extends Number> operand2);
841
842    /**
843     * Creates an implementation-specific function with a single parameter.
844     * The names of available functions is given by {@link #getCapabilities()}.
845     *
846     * @param  name       name of the function to call.
847     * @param  parameter  expression providing values for the function argument.
848     * @return an expression which will call the specified function.
849     * @throws IllegalArgumentException if the given name is not recognized,
850     *         or if the argument is illegal for the specified function.
851     *
852     * @see FilterCapabilities#getFunctions()
853     */
854    @SuppressWarnings({"unchecked", "rawtypes"})
855    default Expression<R,?> function(String name, Expression<R,?> parameter) {
856        return function(name, new Expression[] {
857            Objects.requireNonNull(parameter)
858        });
859    }
860
861    /**
862     * Creates an implementation-specific function with two parameters.
863     * The names of available functions is given by {@link #getCapabilities()}.
864     *
865     * @param  name    name of the function to call.
866     * @param  param1  expression providing values for the first function argument.
867     * @param  param2  expression providing values for the second function argument.
868     * @return an expression which will call the specified function.
869     * @throws IllegalArgumentException if the given name is not recognized,
870     *         or if the arguments are illegal for the specified function.
871     *
872     * @see FilterCapabilities#getFunctions()
873     */
874    @SuppressWarnings({"unchecked", "rawtypes"})
875    default Expression<R,?> function(String name, Expression<R,?> param1, Expression<R,?> param2) {
876        return function(name, new Expression[] {
877            Objects.requireNonNull(param1),
878            Objects.requireNonNull(param2)
879        });
880    }
881
882    /**
883     * Creates an implementation-specific function with an arbitrary number of parameters.
884     * The names of available functions is given by {@link #getCapabilities()}.
885     *
886     * @param  name        name of the function to call.
887     * @param  parameters  expressions providing values for the function arguments.
888     * @return an expression which will call the specified function.
889     * @throws IllegalArgumentException if the given name is not recognized,
890     *         or if the arguments are illegal for the specified function.
891     *
892     * @see FilterCapabilities#getFunctions()
893     */
894    Expression<R,?> function(String name, Expression<R,?>[] parameters);
895
896    /**
897     * Indicates a property by which contents should be sorted, along with intended order.
898     * Implementation may require that the given expression evaluates to {@link Comparable} objects.
899     *
900     * @param  property  the property to sort by.
901     * @param  order     the sorting order, ascending or descending.
902     * @return definition of sort order of a property.
903     */
904    SortProperty<R> sort(ValueReference<R,?> property, SortOrder order);
905}
